item.title: How the Trump-Kim Summit Failed: Big Threats, Big Egos, Bad Bets
item.media:description: President Trump and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, in Hanoi. “A proposal to go big’’ fell short.
item.description: President Trump and Kim Jong-un of North Korea had dramatically different visions of what “denuclearization” meant, dooming their deal.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and EDWARD WONG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Trump Faces Fury After Saying He Believes North Korean Leader on Student’s Death
item.media:description: Fred and Cindy Warmbier, the parents of Otto F. Warmbier, center, who died after being held captive in North Korea, at the State of the Union address on Capitol Hill in 2018.
item.description: The family of Otto Warmbier spoke out after President Trump’s comments, saying that North Korea’s ‘evil regime’ was responsible for the death of their son.
item.dc:creator: JULIE BOSMAN and KEVIN WILLIAMS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Behind Illicit Massage Parlors Lie a Vast Crime Network and Modern Indentured Servitude
item.media:description: Lanyun Ma, 42, left, and Wei Ma, 22, were charged with sex trafficking at a massage parlor in Oxford, Mass., in 2012.
item.description: In a $3 billion-a-year industry, many women stay on as prostitutes in order to pay debts to smugglers, spa owners and lawyers.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KULISH, FRANCES ROBLES and PATRICIA MAZZEI

item.title: Trump’s Black Supporters: Inside a Small and Divided World
item.media:description: Candace Owens spoke at the Conservative Political Action Conference on Friday.
item.description: Most black voters are Democrats, but even among the tiny collection of Mr. Trump’s dedicated black supporters, there are factions.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR, JOHN ELIGON and MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: ‘Collusion Delusion’: Trump Complains About Mueller Inquiry
item.description: In a rambling two-hour speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference, President Trump repeatedly questioned the legitimacy of the investigation into Russian collusion during his presidential campaign.
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Trump Says He Will Sign Free Speech Order for College Campuses
item.description: The president said he planned to issue an executive order that would help guarantee free speech on college campuses by putting their federal aid at risk.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: How Jeff Bezos Went to Hollywood and Lost Control
item.media:description: The Amazon billionaire Jeff Bezos after the Golden Globes in January. In Hollywood, the swirl around his love life refuses to be contained.
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Lippman for The New York Times
item.description: He built the world’s largest fortune with an iron discipline. Now a wild cast of only-in-L.A. characters have seized his narrative.
item.dc:creator: AMY CHOZICK

item.title: After Cuomo’s Calls to Amazon, a Flurry of Conversations to Rally Support
item.media:description: New Yorkers in January showing support for a planned Amazon campus in Queens. After community backlash, the company abandoned the deal.
item.description: An open letter asking Jeff Bezos to resuscitate a plan for Amazon to build a campus in Queens has not seemed to change the company’s position.
item.dc:creator: J. DAVID GOODMAN

item.title: White House Ambitions Cloud Democratic Hopes to Win the Senate
item.media:description: Fellow Democrats have urged Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana to run for Senate, but he is considering a presidential run in 2020.
item.media:credit: Thom Bridge/Independent Record, via Associated Press
item.description: If 2020 produces an anti-Trump wave, Democrats will need plenty of candidates to recapture the Senate. But some of the party’s best only want the White House.
item.dc:creator: GLENN THRUSH

item.title: White House Memo: Mark Penn, Ex-Clinton Loyalist, Visits Trump, and Democrats Are Not Pleased
item.media:description: Mark J. Penn’s meeting with President Trump in the Oval Office was for some former colleagues the inevitable outcome of what they see as his rightward lurch.
item.description: As the Democratic Party has moved to the left, Mr. Penn, with his centrist politics, has become alienated from the party in which he once reigned as a winning pollster.
item.dc:creator: ANNIE KARNI

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Wesley Morris leaves Neverland. New Rembrants and an art feud. Michael J. Fox on acting with Parkinson’s. Hanging up the cellphone. And more.
item.dc:creator: KALY SOTO

item.title: Exposures: ‘What Would I Have Done if I Would Have Killed Her That Night?’
item.description: Ten months in a class for men who hit women.
item.dc:creator: LAUREN JUSTICE

item.title: A Black Woman Will Soon Lead Chicago
item.media:description: Chicago mayoral candidate Toni Preckwinkle.
item.media:credit: Jose M. Osorio/Chicago Tribune, via Associated Press
item.description: President Trump treats Chicago like a punching bag, but its next mayor will break boundaries.
item.dc:creator: NATALIE Y. MOORE

item.title: John Dean: I Testified Against Nixon. Here’s My Advice for Michael Cohen.
item.media:description: John W. Dean being sworn in before reading his statement to the Watergate committee, June 25, 1973.
item.description: My appearance before Congress helped take down a president. Will the same thing happen to Trump?
item.dc:creator: JOHN W. DEAN
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

item.title: The Island That Changed History
item.media:description: Mao Zedong, left, with President Richard Nixon in China in 1972.
item.description: A 1969 border clash between Moscow and Beijing pushed the two apart, and opened the door for Nixon to go to China.
item.dc:creator: SERGEY RADCHENKO

item.title: An Inmate Doesn’t Understand Why He Is to Be Executed. Should He Be Spared?
item.description: The Supreme Court this week rightly ordered Alabama courts to reconsider the death sentence of Vernon Madison, whose memory was damaged by stroke.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: The Supreme Court and Religious Favoritism
item.description: The case of a 40-foot cross in Maryland offers the justices a chance to clarify the constitutionality of religious displays.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: The A.I. Diet
item.description: Forget government-issued food pyramids. Let an algorithm tell you how to eat.
item.dc:creator: ERIC TOPOL

item.title: Donald Trump’s Phony America
item.description: As Michael Cohen made clear, this is the land of the fraud and the home of the knave.
item.dc:creator: FRANK BRUNI

item.title: Let’s Destroy Robocalls
item.description: Finally, something worse than Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: GAIL COLLINS

item.title: Amazon, the Door’s Still Open
item.description: Governor Cuomo is right to try to resuscitate a deal that could help New York.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: An Oscar for the Arabs
item.media:description: The Lebanese filmmaker Nadine Labaki in one of the streets where she shot scenes from her Oscar-nominated film, "Capernaum," in Naaba, a Beirut neighborhood.
item.media:credit: Dalia Khamissy for The New York Times
item.description: But better support is still needed for those in the Middle East who are trying to make quality films.
item.dc:creator: NANA ASFOUR

item.title: The Eagles of Reelfoot Lake
item.description: Why do these birds mean so much to us? Maybe because we almost lost them.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET RENKL and DAMON WINTER

item.title: Q&A: Seth Meyers on Donald Trump, Fatherhood and What He Won’t Joke About
item.media:description: Seth Meyers, photographed in New York on Dec. 19, 2018.
item.description: A wide-ranging conversation with the era’s defining late-night host on the eve of his show’s fifth anniversary.
item.dc:creator: FRANK BRUNI
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Momo Is as Real as We’ve Made Her
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tracy Ma/The New York Times
item.description: Adults are terrified about what their children are seeing online. Should they be?
item.dc:creator: JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: Rites of Passage: There Are No Five Stages of Grief
item.description: When my father died, I wanted desperately to know the timing of this thing. But grief doesn’t have a timeline.
item.dc:creator: ANDY KOPSA

item.title: Weather: Snow and Extreme Cold Forecast for Large Band of the U.S.
item.media:description: The Philadelphia Museum of Art on Friday. Forecasters say New England could get as much as 10 inches of snow starting Sunday night as a large section of the country also contends with dangerously low temperatures.
item.description: Temperatures in the Midwest were expected to be 20 to 30 degrees below normal, with wind chills forecast to reach minus 55 in the Northern Plains.
item.dc:creator: ALI WINSTON

item.title: Deadly Shelling Erupts in Kashmir Between India and Pakistan After Pilot Is Freed
item.media:description: The funeral in Srinagar, Kashmir, on Saturday, of two Indian paramilitary troops killed in a gunfight.
item.description: Several civilians died in intense shelling as the region remained jittery even though tensions between the nuclear-armed neighbors had subsided considerably.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, HARI KUMAR and SAMEER YASIR

item.title: Evidence of Chlorine Found in Syrian Town of Douma, Investigators Say
item.description: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said it found “reasonable grounds” that chlorine was used in an attack on a Damascus suburb last year.
item.dc:creator: ALAN YUHAS
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons

item.title: House in Skripal Nerve Agent Attack Declared Safe, Ending 13,000-Hour Cleanup
item.media:description: An army specialist removes bricks and rubble from the home of the Russian former spy Sergei Skripal in Salisbury, England, Monday, Feb. 4, 2019. British military specialists started to remove the roof of the house where a former Russian spy and his daughter were exposed to the deadly nerve agent Novichok.
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The home where Sergei and Yulia Skripal were poisoned was the last of 13 sites said to be clean after an attack for which Britain has blamed Russia.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Russian General Pitches ‘Information’ Operations as a Form of War
item.media:description: Russian soldiers with no insignia on their uniforms in Crimea in 2014. General Gerasimov said Russia’s armed forces must maintain a mix of combat, intelligence and propaganda tools.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Gen. Valery V. Gerasimov, sometimes credited with inventing Russian “hybrid war,” described modern conflict as a blend of military, economic and political tactics.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Lynch Mobs Killed Latinos Across the West. Descendants Want It Known.
item.description: A marker commemorating the massacre of Mexicans in Texas in 1918 is part of a larger move to recognize the widespread lynchings of Hispanics in the historic Southwest.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: No Charges in Sacramento Police Shooting of Stephon Clark
item.media:description: Sequita Thompson, Mr. Clark’s grandmother, spoke at a news conference last March.
item.description: Mr. Clark was killed in his grandmother’s backyard by officers responding to a vandalism complaint. For nearly a year, activists have demanded police accountability.
item.dc:creator: JOSE A. DEL REAL

item.title: Bernie Sanders Begins 2020 Race With Some Familiar Themes and a New One: Himself
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders held his first rally as a 2020 presidential candidate at Brooklyn College on Saturday.
item.description: Throughout his political career, Mr. Sanders has focused on policy, not personal details. But as he kicked off his second presidential bid, he did something new: He talked about his own life story.
item.dc:creator: SYDNEY EMBER

item.title: Roots of Spain’s Crisis: One Word Fought Over at Birth of Constitution
item.media:description: Demonstrators marching in support of the imprisoned Catalan leaders in Barcelona, Spain, in February.
item.description: A triumph at the time, Spain’s 1978 Constitution refers to constituent “nationalities,” a compromise that has left the country in a deadlock today.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: How to Support a Friend or Loved One Who Has Been Sexually Abused
item.description: It’s been a particularly difficult few months for sexual abuse survivors. If you know someone who’s been abused, here are some tips to best support them and their recovery.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA MARIN

item.title: Playlist: The Playlist: Solange’s Surprise, and 14 More New Songs
item.media:description: Solange released a new album, “When I Get Home,” early Friday with little notice.
item.media:credit: Bennett Raglin/Getty Images for 2017 ESSENCE Festival
item.description: Hear tracks by Jackie Mendoza, Matmos, Kehlani, L7 and others.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA, CARYN GANZ and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: 12 New Books to Watch for in March
item.description: Preet Bharara on justice, a chronicle of gun violence in Chicago, a grown-up fairy tale and more.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB
item.category: Madame Fourcade's Secret War: The Daring Young Woman Who Led France's Largest Spy Network Against Hitler (Book)
So Much Longing in So Little Space: The Art of Edvard Munch (Book)

item.title: The Palmy Days of a South Beach Shtetl
item.description: Andy Sweet’s photographs and a new film tell the story of a vanished Jewish community on the tip of Miami Beach that gave way to a glittering American Riviera.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH B. TREASTER

item.title: Eat: A Simple Citrus Salad to Brighten Up the Dead of Winter
item.media:description: Citrus salad with peanuts and avocado.
item.media:credit: Paola & Murray for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Angharad Bailey.
item.description: There’s really no need for leafy greens in this big, varied and meaty salad.
item.dc:creator: TEJAL RAO

item.title: Fiction: A Brilliantly Funny and Slightly Bonkers New Novel From Jasper Fforde
item.description: In “Early Riser,” Fforde explores the strange things that happen when humans begin hibernating during ice age-like winters.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES YU

item.title: Sports of The Times: Can LeBron James Teach Baseball Players What They Forgot?
item.media:description: Baseball players sail toward a possible confrontation with the owners without leaders who possess the cultural cachet and business power of basketball’s LeBron James.
item.description: Star signings aside, baseball players are struggling to get the contracts they want, and they see the N.B.A. as ascendant. What went wrong?
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL POWELL

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: After 31 Years, Farewell to the Met Opera’s Grand, Gaudy ‘Aida’
item.media:description: A scene from the Metropolitan Opera’s utterly traditional, utterly delightful production of “Aida,” which plays for two more performances before being retired.
item.description: A critic admits his love for an utterly traditional, utterly delightful production that will be replaced in the 2020-21 season.
item.dc:creator: ZACHARY WOOLFE

item.title: Have Dark Forces Been Messing With the Cosmos?
item.description: Axions? Phantom energy? Astrophysicists scramble to patch a hole in the universe, rewriting cosmic history in the process.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: Trilobites: How the Icefish Got Its Transparent Blood and See-Through Skull
item.media:description: The blackfin icefish, Chaenocephalus aceratus, lacks hemoglobin and lives in Antarctic waters, where the temperature is often close to the freezing point of seawater.
item.media:credit: Doug Allan/Nature Picture Library, via Minden Pictures
item.description: Research shows how the Antarctic blackfin icefish differs from its close relatives on the genetic level.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: The New Old Age: Supplements Won’t Prevent Dementia. But These Steps Might.
item.media:description: Donna Kaye Hill walking with her dog, Annie, in Danville, Va. She takes fish oil daily to stave off dementia, but research suggests it may be exercise that really helps reduce her risk.
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.description: Scientists still have no magic shield against Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias. Yet there is evidence that some strategies may help.
item.dc:creator: PAULA SPAN
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine

item.title: Theodore Bayless, Pathbreaker on Dairy Intolerance, Dies at 87
item.description: His research led to commercial innovations for people whose bodies reject milk products, and to better treatments for other gastrointestinal diseases.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
